remarks: If we have a conditional equality proof, where ` ph ` is ` ph ( x ) ` and ` ps ` is ` ph ( y ) ` , and ` ph ( x ) ` in fact does not have ` x ` free in it according to ` F/ ` , then ` ph ( x ) <-> ph ( y ) ` unconditionally.  This proves that ` F/ x ph ` is actually a not-free predicate.  (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Aug-2016.)
statement:
nfcdeq.1 $e |- F/ x ph $.
nfcdeq.2 $e |- CondEq ( x = y -> ( ph <-> ps ) ) $.
nfcdeq $p |- ( ph <-> ps ) $.
$d ph y $.
$d ps x $.
